sanskrit:
चञ्चलं हि मनः कृष्ण प्रमाथि बलवद्दृढम्।
तस्याहं निग्रहं मन्ये वायोरिव सुदुष्करम्॥
transliteration:
cañcalaṁ hi manaḥ kṛṣṇa pramāthi balavad dṛḍham |
tasyāhaṁ nigrahaṁ manye vāyor iva suduṣkaram ||
translation: The mind is indeed restless, O Krishna, turbulent, powerful, and obstinate. I consider its control to be as difficult as controlling the wind.
commentary:
In this verse, Arjuna expresses his honest doubt about the practical feasibility of the meditation practice Krishna has been describing. He characterizes the mind with four significant qualities: restless (chanchala), turbulent or agitating (pramathi), powerful (balavat), and obstinate or unyielding (dridha). These qualities make the mind extremely difficult to master. Arjuna's comparison of controlling the mind to controlling the wind is particularly apt—just as wind is invisible, constantly moving, and impossible to grasp physically, so too is the mind elusive and difficult to restrain.

This verse is significant because it represents the genuine struggle that every spiritual aspirant faces. Arjuna is not merely being pessimistic; he is voicing the universal human experience of attempting meditation and finding the mind wandering constantly. His candid admission creates an opportunity for Krishna to provide practical guidance in the following verses. The metaphor of the wind also suggests that while control may be difficult, it is not impossible—wind can be channeled and directed, just as the mind can be trained through practice and detachment. This verse validates the challenges of the spiritual path while setting the stage for Krishna's reassuring response about the methods of gradually mastering the mind through abhyasa (practice) and vairagya (dispassion).
speaker: Arjuna
